item.title: Teaser
item.dc:creator: marie
item.content:encoded:
A new WIP has presented itself to me. Parts of it I've been working through in other ways, but I restarted the idea, trying to use the Snowflake method to see how that works out for me.

This is going to be the first in an epic fantasy YA story set in a world of myths and legends. It follows a young Jarl, Vanlandi, and his wife Lynessa, as they quest to save their world from eternal darkness. All teasers are from different parts of the process, though will be occasionally revised once the stories are.

Descriptions

Vanlandi

Tall, especially for his age, with broad shoulders. He is toned and curvy, with ruddy, weatherworn skin. His eyes are a dark, deep blue, which shifts into tones of grey when he's angry. His dark honey blond hair hangs down below his shoulders: straight with a few braids to keep it in place. As he prefers to not show of his peaked hairline, it's rarely pulled back completely. His face is square, with a beaked nose, cleft chin and high cheekbones. A slender scar crosses his left eyebrow, sewn t together with crude stitches. His gaze under blond eyebrows flickers around any area he is in, with every movement conserving energy and preparing for a yet-unknown ambush.

Lynessa

She is slender and lithe, with hair that shifts in bands of red and brown and hangs down her back in thick curls. Her face is pale with expressive, dark eyebrows and long, black eyelashes that contrast against hazel eyes shifting in dark green and gold. With high cheekbones that are touched by pink and a slight chin she has a fragile and delicate appearance.

Vanlandi Sveigdersson, of Yngling line

Born to Sveigder Fjolnersson and Vana Eorundsdottir I was my father's desperately longed for son. He taught me all he could, raising me a hunter, a warrior, a tactician. I was barely sixteen winters when a stray boar skewered him during a hunt, leaving me Jarl of the Ynglingaline.

We had enemies, many who would do anything to destroy us. One of them, unfortunately, was my own uncle, Agne Eorundsson. He had never forgiven my father for taking my mother. As if he had any say in the path of a man to his woman! Another enemy was that Lowlander king, Alderan of Keer, whose father Amalric my father killed in war. Any sign of weakness on my part and the wolves would feast. I would not, could not, allow that.

Alderan of Keer had a daughter, Lynessa. I had seen her as I scried using the Mirror in my keep. Peasants might get away with stealing their brides from their neighbours with only a few buddies to stop them from taking their price, but I was a Jarl. Only the most dangerous heists would do, so I gathered twenty of my best warriors in a raid on Haith, the capital of Keer. The Wild Hunt rode again, and I came back victorious with my bride. She was a strange one, though. Seeing me without clothes on she called me a woman, as if my body would decide that!

I had even before I took her decided that we would not be intimate, not that soon. Since she was not used to our customs, it was better to wait until she was more used to her own position in my magical Keep, carved out of the glacier we make our home, high up in the North, above the Lowlands.

We were the only ones who could tame the mares and stallions of the icy winds, and the Keep was my ancestral home. No other tribes have ever found a gem such as it, and it's worth defending until death. Unfortunaly, war wasn't the only defense we need to mount. We also had to play politics. A good thing my mother was a Vala. She had trained me in things my warrior father never learned---never had any need to learn ---as he could take anyone in even an unfair fight.

Then, as if we needed more complications, we saw the Rider's horse falter. The Wolf saw its' chance, and then the Sun-Child was gone. I I could only do one thing: I set the Council to keep the clan together and prepared to find the Sun-Child and the Wolf, to save our worlds from endless darkness. The Runes demanded I not go alone, and they also named my companion: My wife. Wonderful. How could I do what I needed to if I was needing to slow down to let her keep up? At least she knew how to ride, though she'd never ridden a stallion, especially not one as powerful as our horses.

Our first stop on the way was to quest through the Far Country. That is the land of fairy tales, bound by rules strange to most. We met the Nornir, finally, the Three who see what Was, what Is, and what Should be. They, too, are bound by their nature, and their nature demanded we both be tried in Trials Three. Waiting for Lynessa to finish hers was a nightmare. She had made it quite clear that she didn't want to be my wife, so I knew I had to let her go. No one would worry about my first wife once the Sun-Child was back, so I would not lose face in letting her return to her people. My heart, maybe, but I was a Jarl. Sacrifices need to be made to keep strength.

The Norns could not tell us where the Wolf lay, only that the one who could know was the Morrigan, bound into a Sword by a king before a battle years ago, long before I or Lynessa were born. She, however, recognized the story. The king was her grandfather Amalric of Keer, which meant I knew which battle the Norns were talking about: The one where my father killed him. Apparently binding an ancient portent of War and Death into a sword doesn't in fact save you from your fate.

I don't do groveling. I certainly don't do subtlety, but I understood that we needed diplomacy to be able to get the Mirror of the Morrigan from Alderan. It would've helped if Lynessa had told me how crazy her father was, since he apparently wanted to marry Lynessa. She had mentioned that Lowlanders apparently "arrange" marriages for their children---what a strange concept! Why would you give away a daughter like that? How would you know that the new husband could protect her? ---but it was the first I heard of fathers marrying daughters. So, he told his guards to seize us. I couldn't get away myself, but I made sure that Lynessa did.

Apparently while I was chained up in the dungeon, Lynessa figured out a plan to free me. Not really sure I like being rescued by my wife--- that certainly would not help my reputation---but it's preferrable to being a guest of Alderan's. Together we fled Keer with the bound Morrigan. I knew quite certainly that she would leave us to fend for ourselves if we freed her, and she admitted as much. However, in return for her help she made us swear to free her once we had found the Wolf, which we agreed to.

It wasn't easy. The gods know that. The Wolf laired high up in the North, far beyond places I've ever been. If it hadn't been for our stallions I'm not sure we would have been able to get there, but finally we did. The Wolf attacked us as soon as we entered his cave, which we expected. We won through a drawn-out battle, though even as we stood victorious over the Wolf, that was just the beginning. The child was safe, but the Sun needs the be carried across the sky by the Rider, and the Rider was no where to be found.

And thus, we needed to travel up into the heavens to track down the Rider. At least we had light.

Lynessa of Keer

I grew up hearing how beautiful my mother had been. Elaisse her name was, and she died when I was only two years old. My father, Alderan, was the king of Keer, and I his only heir, as he refused to marry anyone that could not match her beauty. When I was fourteen he stopped looking at me like a father looks at his daughter. Thhat's when I started hoping that someone would come and rescue me. I used to look through the window, daydreaming that a stranger would come and sweep me off my feet. When it finally happened it was closer to a nightmare.

While growing up my Nanny used to tell me stories about the Wild Hunt. Barbarians, probably not even human, she said. The were half-human, half-beast, riding on flying horses born out of the North wind. They stole women and children, as well as anything else that wasn't nailed down. They came with the storms, warning all of the danger. I always thought that you'd be safe if you weren't inside, but that's before Vanlandi smashed my window and pulled me out of my tower.

Vanlandi ... I still don't really get it. Things were very simple at home. I expected to be married off to some man, hopefully a fairly young one, and then we'd live together happily. If ... we weren't happy we'd both find ourselves a mistress. That's how things should be. Right? Instead I found myself supposedly married to a smelly barbarian woman, and to make things worse, apparently he's seen as a man to his people. I really wanted someone to come and rescue me, but while waiting I played the Lady of the Keep, since that was what was expected of me. Vanlandi always wanted to be far too direct, but with the Vala's help I could guide ... him. I knew enough about politics from home, even if I hadn't expected to use it that soon.

And then just ... I'd heard legends about the Sun being a child carried across the sky in the arms of the Rider, hunted by a Wolf, but I never thought I'd see that it was the literal truth. The Vala---apparently Vanlandi's mother?---said that I had go with him. I was a little bit excited about that, honestly. I'd gone from my tower to Vanlandi's keep and I was looking forward to see what else there was, even if it was covered in darkness. And the horse! I had ridden a few times at home, but that was on a gentle little mare. The stallion I was given was huge! I slowly learned to know him though, and he is a darling when given the chance.

Before we left, the Vala brought me to the Crone's Council. They told me about magic, about the path to the Far Country, and that it would be me to lead us into the Far Country itself, since I was a woman, and magic is nothing for a man. Weird, really. Of course it is, everyone knows that only men should do magic; women are too gentle creatures to struggle with the forces of nature like that. But since they told me what to do, I remembered it.

I guess that Vanlandi really is a nice guy. He liked to tease me by kissing my neck, but he'd made it clear that very first night that he wouldn't touch me against my will. I think I hurt him, though. I didn't want to like him, so every time he tried to be nice I rebuffed him. Until he stopped, and I kind-of realised how much I'd liked it. And him.

At any rate, we travelled through the fairy tale land of the Folk, questing for the Nornir. They refused to help us unless we were willing to go through three trials each. I think the one thing that really stuck with me was their defense on why: Because they are bound to their nature.

Turns out, we had to go back home. I had to face my father, with a husband. He reacted ... predictably. At first he pretended to listen, but soon he ordered his guards to arrest us. Vanlandi was his normal heroic self and threw himself in the way, yelling at me to get out, so I ran.

I had to do something. At first I waited, hoping someone would help me, and then it occured to me. I'd spent my entire life waiting for someone to save me. It's the way I was raised, of course, but I shouldn't keep thinking that way. I'd seen the Vala. I'd seen the way that Vanlandi acted. I realised that though the Nornir were bound by their own nature, I was not. I was not bound by anything. I found my old Nanny and asked her to help me. We made a plan, I snuck in, rescued Vanlandi and grabbed the sword. I don't think that Vanlandi liked it too much, and I'm not sure how to tell him why. That I did it because I like him, and that I don't actually want to leave him anymore.

It was really hard to follow the Morrigan's directions. Cold, dark and far outside of any kind of civilization. The Morrigan taught me how to fight a bit, and Vanlandi did too. Turns out that in the end, finding the Wolf wasn't the end of our quest. It was the beginning.

On the plus side? With the Sun-Child free, we have light!

Vana Eorundsdottir, of Ylfing line

Sveigder was twice my age, but the moment I saw him I knew I wanted him and no one else. My own parents died when I was three years old, and I rarely saw my older brother, Agne. I think Agne had intended to make sure that whoever stole me from my family would be someone of his choosing, but he learned the hard way that women are not merchandise or commodities to be bargained with.

Of course, I wasn't Sveigder's first wife. I was the first one to bear him a child, though. His first wife---the love of his youth---died in consumption only a few years after they married. Then he married Ketilriðr. She was widowed to one of his warriors, but she was unable to give him the child he needed. They parted ways aimably, but I'm fairly certain she hated me. Anyways, my brother was celebrating the birth of his firstborn the year I turned sixteen. He'd made sure I was prettied up for ... whomever he had decided would make a suitable man for me. Instead, I made sure Sveigder saw me. Saying farewell in the evening he dragged me up his horse before Agne could even react. I knew my brother was weak, and he hated Sveigder for it.

In his keep I had my first vision. I was chosen to speak for the spirits, granting me the title of 'Vala'. When I gave Sveigder the child he'd longed for I prayed that the spirits would name it a son, and they did. Sveigder finally had the heir he wanted and deserved.

It hurt so much when he died. I'd never imagined it. But at least I knew that Vanlandi would be able to handle it; he was born to be a leader. I took a step back, as it is traditional of the old Jarl's widow, hiding myself behind being the Vala. We as a people are proud, and we do not grieve in public.

I was concerned when Vanlandi choose Lynessa as his wife. I understood and agreed with the politics behind it---it showed that he was not one to be trifled with---but she was young and innocent, and she didn't understand our culture. Without letting her know who I was, I made sure to present myself as a trusted ally. I encouraged her friendship with the servant girl Serria, and I listened to her concerns while guiding her through how to be the Jarl's wife. To her credit, she was a natural Lady of the Keep. I also saw how my son fell in love with her, and her falling in love with him, and that both of them were too proud. I think Vanlandi was afraid to scare her off, since she was a bit of a delicate flower, and she didn't want to admit that she preferred her life with us to her life at home.

When the Sun was stolen, Vanlandi didn't have a choice. We both knew that. An army wouldn't help, but I hoped that a single young woman might. We'll see if she'll grow with the responsibility I and the Crones put on her slender shoulders.

Agne Eorundsson, of Ylfing line

Disrespectful simpletons all! Sveigder was always a boisterous and loud man. I tolerated him because of his power, and because the Ice Keep Tribe were in a better position than mine was. I had intended to make sure that I tied the Folkung to us by having their Jarl take my sister.

My parents died when I was nineteen years old, and I took over the tribe as its' Jarl. I had plans to grow our strength, though unfortunately some of those plans hinged on the mewling brat that was my younger sister growing up. She filled up nicely, though, so the year she turned sixteen it was time. It luckily coincided with the birth of my daughter Sòlveig to my Skjalf, so I had a good excuse to arrange festivities.

You can imagine my humiliation as Sveigder Fjolnersson grabbed my sister as he left. She held onto him, giving me a triumphant look as they rode off on his great white stallion. I can never live down the shame of not even having enough warning to try to ward off my sister's suitor. People laugh at me behind my back. What kind of man would not be able to defend their own family? Curse Sveigder, and curse my sister!

I was certain that I would get my chance to take charge of the tribe when Sveigder met his death at the end of a wild boar's skewering. After all, my nephew Vanlandi was barely sixteen winters old. He surprised me, though. I never expected him to be that worthy an adversary. I was expecting to win, however, despite that young thing he took as his.

And then darkness. My revenge would have to wait. Armies can not be launched in the night.

Serria

Me? I'm just a peasant girl. Third child of five. We were dirt poor, and my parents were just looking for a man to unburden them of me when I did something that I'm still not sure if it was a mistake or the best thing I could've done: I fell asleep outside.

When I woke up, a sudden storm had hit us, and I fought to find my way home. Before I could get into the safety of our little hut I heard the whinny of a horse and was scooped up on a giant stallion by a furred creature. Or, as it turned out, by a warrior in a heavy cloak. He pulled me against him, making sure I was bundled up against the cold.

His name was Aghi. Apparently he had seen me outside a few times and wanted me as his. I could certainly have done worse. He never hit me, he didn't drink himself into a stupor and he was a good provider. I think that's why I wanted to comfort Princess Lynessa when she came to the keep. She was terrified, and a bit naive. Considering how she was raised, probably not too surprising. She seemed to be looking for someone to rescue her.

The dowager queen---though they don't call her that, I'm not sure what the difference between her title and that of a queen would be---was a very kind woman, though stern. She made sure that Princess Lynessa and I could have a friendship which I think we both needed. Even with Aghi and the littles I occasionally felt like a stranger here.

The Nornir

Urthr, Skuld and Verthandi

We are the Nornir. We see what was, what is, and what must happen. Know that there is a difference between what must happen and what will happen. You are not bound by fate in your actions. However, what must happen is that Lynessa finds the strength within to save Vanlandi in his day of need, and that they both agree to deal given to them by the Morrigan. If not, they will perish, and the hopes of man will become futile.

Alderan of Keer

When my father, Amalric of Keer, showed me the miniature of my future wife I immediately fell in love with her. Elaisse was such a lovely creature. Gentle, beautiful. I could never imagined marrying another woman, despite her not having given me an heir. That is, until I saw Lynessa grow into womanhood, the spitting image of her mother. Then I knew that I had to marry her. It was the final gift from my beloved.

Then she was taken from me again. Kidnapped from the very tower I had locked her in to ensure she was safe. By the same despicable creatures that killed my father. Of course, they had been in league with the Morrigan, of that I'm certain. Why else would she have spoken of our defeat?

My father knew how to deal with that kind of ilk, though. She had come on his bidding, but when she told him that what she saw was his destruction he had her arrested and her spirit bound into a Sword for him to bring with him as we faced off against the so-called Wild Hunt. We would have won, too, had not the Sword turned against him. I saw how the leader of the Hunt killed my father. I swore to destroy them for that, and then they took my beloved daughter.

Then the darkness struck. All I could do was to try to keep the country together. Imagine my shock when Lynessa returned, and with that. My beautiful daughter, daring to bring into my home a barbarian, one of the creatures who'd killed my father. In fact, the son of my father's killer. She called herself his wife, and they talked about the Sword. Something delusional about the darkness and it being due to the mythical Wolf. Seeing my chance to bring her back I ordered my guards to seize the monster. It hurt me that Lynessa rather than taking the chance to come back home fled.

She must have been brainwashed by the barbarians, because she wasn't the gentle woman I had raised, but rather a sassy one that spoke back. She had been destroyed.

The Morrigan

You know who I am. I am the Morrigan, queen of war and strife. While my sisters, the Nornir, speak of what was, what is and what should be, I only see what will be: Who will die, who will win, who will stand victorious as the bloody mists water the ground. In fact, who will stand at all.

Many years ago, per the counting of mortals, I was summoned to council a King of the Lowlands, in the country of Keer. He was fated to die at the hand of Sveigder of the North, and I told him as much. He did not appreciate my council. I believe he thought that his death meant the death of his kingdom. A foolish man, Amalric of Keer. He believed he could intimidate me.

Unfortunately, I underestimated his perseverance. He bound me with Magic of Iron into a sword which he mockingly called the Mirror of Morrigan. How I detested that man. Uncouth, uncivilized, unmannered. He brought me with him when he tried to invade the northern glaciers, but he learned that it's complicated when your opponents have flying horses.

I killed in his name, while biding my time. Finally I saw him: Sveigder Fjolnersson. He fought bravely, and I guided him closer. The battle was magnificent, and though Sveigder's sword broke in his hands he fought on. Amalric lost his grip on me, and Sveigder took me, giving me my revenge. Perhaps things would have ended up differently if not Alderan had come to his father's defense, driving off Sveigder and his kinsmen in frenzied rage. Or maybe not. Perhaps this is what was bid to happen.

I fell asleep waiting to be freed, and then I was awoken by Vanlandi. I would known him everywhere, he is surprisingly like his father. Also, where Amalric was delusional, I believe that Vanlandi isn't. He also doesn't need my help, which is why I ensured that Lynessa wielded me. The little one is not as much of a wishy-washy airhead as she might come off as, but she needs help to mature into that which she is fated to become. Her father might have doted on her in his sick desire for her, but he did not do her any favours.

The Huntress

Let me tell you a story.

Once upon a time---and why no one knows---the Rider scooped up Sunne, the Sun-Child in its' arms. On Skinfaxi they started riding across the sky. In hot pursuit came Skoll, a giant Wolf intent on swallowing the child whole. Perhaps the Rider had offended the Wolf? No one knows why Skoll hates the Rider and Sunne so much, but we could not let the Wolf destroy this youngest of our Celestials.

We were the Star-Maidens, who give light during the night. Sunne shines the brightest of all of us, and through her ride across the sky, she grants that light to the worlds below. My light is nearly as strong, and my skills with the spear superior to anyone else. So, therefor, I chose to mount Hrimfaxi and pursue the Wolf. We ride in perfect harmony over the sky, and every so often I come closer, hiding my light under my hood, before the Rider finds new strength and we are once again off.

Every night my sisters help me light up the night, and every day I rest as Sunne lights up the day, banishing all that is dark. That is, until something quite unexpected happened: Skinfaxi faltered.

That should never have happened again. But because it did, the Wolf saw its' chance, and snatched Sunne out of the arms of the Rider, snuffing out the light of day.

At first we reeled. I knew that I should go after Skoll, but if I did, how would the worlds get any light? I saw the Rider flee deep into the darker corners of the sky, and all I could do was hope that one of the mortals would be strong enough to take up the mantle. I sent out the call for my sisters to scour the worlds for that one hero. One by one they sent me messages stating that the Lowlanders lacked such heroes. So did the Far Country, and all the other countries. I had almost given up in despair when a little boy came flying. He spoke of a Jarl, Vanlandi of the line of Yngling, of the frozen North, of the Wild Hunt. He had travelled out with his wife, Lynessa of Keer, a Lowlander. As much as I wanted to do something, I knew that it was in the hands of the Nornir, but I ensured that there would be someone always keeping an eye on the development.

I knew that the Lowlanders had stopped "believing" in us. Their strange new advisors were speaking of Science, of us not existing, so it did not surprise me that they did nothing. The people of the Far Country are too bound by their own laws to be able to act. The only one with enough power to break out of that mold is the Morrigan, and she disappeared from our view many years ago

From time to time I was given reports that Vanlandi and Lynessa were moving forward. They found their way through the tasks set before them, and they even found the Morrigan. I made sure to get closer to Skoll's cave as they did, since I knew that they would get there. I waited, ready to step in, but letting them take the fight. After all, I knew something they didn't: Their task would not be done through the Wolf being defeated. They would need to rise higher, find their way through the world of the Celestials. Maybe even find the secret hidden in Millennia: Who is the Rider?

Ansgot, son of Wy, Captain of the Royal Guard

Ï am Ansgot, son of Wy and Hadwisa. My father was a mercenary during the wars that Amalric of Keer started against, among others, the southern reaches. During one of the raids he found my mother and brought her back as a price, since he was high enough ranked that he could afford supporting a concubine. He once told me that his biggest regret was that he could not marry my mother, but it was just not done.

While I grew up I was tormented as a bastard and half-breed, but I learned how to keep my temper. When I was old enough to join the army, I did. I rose through the ranks, especially after saving the life of Prince Alderan. He personally promoted me to Captain of the Guard after his father's death in war, and he's earned my loyalty.

My mother used to warn me about him, though. She said that she saw darkness in him, but I refused to listen. I saw an honourable man, even if he did make mistakes occasionally.

I'm not sure when I realised how far off the deep end he'd gone. Maybe when he started making plans to replace his dead wife with his daughter. I certainly saw it when darkness hit. He didn't know how to deal with it, understandably, but he shut himself in his keep and refused to listen to his people. And then Princess Lynessa returned, with her husband.

He ordered us to seize the ... boy, and we did. He ordered us to throw him into the dungeons, and we did. I ordered the guards to not lay a finger on the young Jarl, at least for now. There is no honour in torture, especially not of a prisoner of war.

It was then that my loyalty and admiration for him died. He tried to stop the two people I'd heard of that were actively trying to restore our world, and for what? His sick desire for his daughter, and a misplace need for retribution over the death of his father, so many years ago.

I have to say that it was strange to see the young princess again. She was very different. More self-assured. Less vapid. That's why, when I heard that she was looking to free her husband, I discreetly made sure that she was aware of my change in allegiance. I may still be punished for it, but I did the right thing, and if I die it is with my conscious clear.

item.title: Harlow Whittaker & the Soothsayers
item.dc:creator: webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Stars: 4

Review

Harlow Whittaker is a spunky nineteen-year-old who prefers sarcasm to letting people in. Her broken heart (due to her ex's inability to accept the vision she had of her dead grandmother when she was twelve) quickly mends as she meets Larken. Can he be more dreamy? Motorcycle, leatherjacket, black angelic wings ...

She is the first human soothsayer, and now she needs to find the other soothsayers, preferrably before one of the myriad of headhunters and other unsavoury creatures gets to her. By her side she has three guardians, known as Archers. Larken can travel through the worlds easier, Fin is a healer, and Hendrix has charms that can do the most impressive things.

Do they reach the Soothsayers? Now, that would be telling!

This is a really good read. A modern fantasy with interesting characters and nicely layered conflicts and action. I recommend it wholeheartedly, as it's very well written. The sequel is coming out in June 2014.

The one thing that lowers the grade from 5 stars down to "only" 4 is that it's lacking some in the editing. The point of views are occasionally a bit strange, and the occasional sentence is a touch awkward. However, don't let that stop you from reading it. Valerie Day-Sánchez spins a very, very vivid world.

item.dc:creator: webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Warning, this is first draft material, and not finished. Brownie points to anyone who can figure out which span of history this starts in.

The second knock was less patient than the first one. She ignored it, still. Her hands were covered with grime, the humming of the engine interspersed with the clunking of a loose cog. The loose cog she was trying to find, to be exact.

"Augustín!" It was Henry, one of the younger recruits on the Seadragon. "Augustín! The captain wants a word."

Right. She shook her head as she crawled back from underneath the heavy machinery, wiping her hands on the towel next to the door. It did little to clean up the oil, but gave her the defense of having tried.

She slipped her bare feet into the heavy boots, pulling a hand through her oily locks. Clonk. Clonk. Clonk. An annoyed glance over at the engine followed by a well-placed fist put the fear of God into the machine.

"Right." She looked over at Henry. He was a gangly youth, gaunt with dirty tests of blonde hair hanging into his blue eyes. "What is this all about, then?" She didn't bother pitching down her voice; no one here would doubt her abilities or question her worth. A grin crossed her features. Not twice, at any rate.

"Captain didn't say." He kept his eyes averted. "Just said to get you."

She nodded, following him to the deck. Her balance on the swaying deck was perfect, compensating for the waves. Henry knew how to compensate as well. "You were a fisherman before you were recruited?" Her English melodic, with a hint of the Spanish lilt that betrayed, if her colouring and name didn't, her heritage.

"Yes. Navy ... recruited me first, though." His face darkened. "I prefer the Seadragon."

"I would too." She shrugged, stepping up on deck. Karl Stranne, once of Smögen, steered. The ship followed his every movement. She stole a moment of admiration for the winsome sailor with the steady hands. "Captain, you wanted to see me?" A hint of annoyance in her voice.

He smirked in response. "Agustín, you are not irreplaceable." His afro hair cropped short, the long scar across his face--which had given him the nickname Serendipitous--tugged at his lips.

She grinned, teasingly winking. "Begging you pardon, Captain, but yes, I am." She straightened up. "What can I do for you, Captain?"

François le Fortuite pointed into the distance. She accepted the tube, following the line of a ship with her gaze. "She is taking in water. I don't see any men aboard."

"How long do you think she's got before she goes under?"

"Hard to say, though we should be able to reach her, if that's what you're asking."

"Would she have any of those ... things you're wanting for the engine?" He slipped his thumb into the armpit of his worn vest, his shoulders broad.

"She might." She studied the ship, with doubt creeping into her voice. "It's hard to tell from here. All I can say is that she isn't an ironclad, and you didn't need me to tell you that."

"Hmm." Rubbing his goatee he pursed his lips in thought. She waited patiently. Few men were as good at analyzing a situation correctly with so few facts. "Very well. Go back to your engine. We should reach her in a couple of hours. Be ready for it."

She had barely settled in the parts of the engine that weren't too hot or too dangerous when a knock once again disturbed her concentration.

"What?" She bit back a sharper response.

"Captain says we're approaching the ship." Henry again. Had he been appointed 'first engineer-botherer' when she wasn't looking?

She slid back from underneath the machinery. "Right, I'll be out there in a moment."

This close, the frigate looked even shabbier than she had from the distance. "The Sultry Mermaid" The captain raised an eyebrow, and she nodded towards the name on the side.

"Oh." He shrugged, busying himself with the tube. "Alright, men, she looks abandoned! Allez! Toute de suite!" François lead the charge on the ghost ship. She checked the short sword and the revolver before following him.

The smell of the ocean was heavy on the creaking Mermaid. She sniffed, but it was just rotting wood and seaweed, not rotting flesh. "Henry, on me." Her voice soft as she moved down into the engine room. Water was reaching up to her ankles as she moved through the inside of the ship. The cold was numbing, and she checked her sword by pure instinct.

The shriek of a banshee echoed through the engine room as a ghost attacked her. She stumbled backwards, fumbling to get the ghast off of her. Finding soft fur under her hands she relaxed a touch, especially as the tail was covered in fur as well.

The kitten was soaking wet, which explained the shriek, shaking. She lift it up by the neck ruff and studied it. "Poor thing is starving." Wrapping it up in her bandanna she stuffed the critter into a spare pocket, ignoring its' indignant meowing. "Let's see what else we have here ..."

Very little was salvageable, but she'd found a diary and some things that she and Henry had been able to pry off the dead engine. The kitten looked like a black, fluff ball as it lay next to her.

François stepped into her cabin after a quick rap on the door, interrupting her reading. "Anything useful?"

She shook her head. "The diary has some interesting ideas, but I think that the most useful thing is going to be the ship cat." She marked the passage she was on, closing the book. "Did you find anything useful?"

"Some food. They'd cleaned it out fairly well before they left. Did you see any reason why they abandoned ship?"

"Engine was broke, and considering how much water she was taking in ..." She tapped her lower lip. "I've been thinking, Captain ..."

"Do you ever do anything else?" The amused tone taking the sting out of the words.

"Well, I could stop thinking, but then Eduardo would've lost that leg completelly." She winked at him. "Anyways, I've seen some interesting designs, both to speed the engine up--once I finally manage to find what is making that rattling sound--and do you remember seeing that airship prototype I think it would be really really interesting to--"

He put a finger on her lips. "Breathe, Agustín. You know that is your department. Don't do anything too big to the ship without talking to me, ma cherie, but when it's just thinking ..."

She nodded, stretching out her body some. "Very well, Captain. I'll be in here until my watch. I have some things to catch up on."

She looked over at the purring kitten, mussing its' black fur. It nipped at her fingers. She tapped it on the nose, shifting to her native Spanish. "Silly cat. I saved you, remember?" Tugging the cat to her lap, it settled with its' head on her knee, wrapping its' frontpaws around her wrist. "That is making it difficult to read, little one."

The diary was in a legible English print, with only a few smudges and inkblots. In between notes of the daily work were sketches and schematics. "Minerva, I wish I could've talked to this one. He has some brilliant ideas." She flipped to the front. "Vivian Allgood. I shall keep that in mind." The cat purred, a steady vibration.

Together with the content of the diary it helped her shut out the rest of the world. Cogwheels and intricate details of machinery danced alongside sketches of fastenings and sweeping sails formed just so.

Eduardo scurried down the rigging from the crow's nest, hopping like an actual crow. Landing in front of her, the clicking of his mechanical leg sent pleasant shivers up her spine.

"Is it working well?" She nodded towards the leg, speaking in Spanish.

He responded in his native Portuguese, supplemented with a broad grin. "Yes. How did you ..." waving his hand, adding in English. "Make it move?"

"Simple. Just a matter of ..." At Eduardo's blank stare she shrugged. "Ciencia"

He flashed a grin that exposed broken and missing teeth. His gait not as graceful on the deck, the clicking and whirring of the cogwheels as they kept up with his movements more pronounced; keeping the foot parallel to the dock in the rolls of the ship.

She stretched out in the crow's nest, before settling down. Long, mind-numbing hours of staring out over the sea, glittering in gold and oranges as the sun set, awaited her. Dividing her thoughts into the part that had to--and did--watch for signs of trouble or profit, and the part that soared like the albatrosses above. A small bird hopped across the water, then another of the same species. And another one. Mother Carey's Chickens!

The tube confirmed the warning, supplemented by the scent of the approaching storm. She rang the bell, for once not paying attention to the sweet tone as it rang across the deck. Hopping down, François met her below.

"How bad?" Scratching his shoulder.

"Bad." She held out the tube. He cursed. The sky was black at the horizon.

As François started barking out orders, she sprinted to the engine room. "Come on, come on ..."

They had enough time to prepare, and once Agustín felt secure in the engine not breaking in the heavy movements she sprinted back up on deck, wrapped up in an oilskin coat and heavy boots.

Even through that she was soon drenched once the storm hit. The sails were secured, and as much as they could--including Karl Stranne, the pilot--was tied down. Only way to weather a storm this big was to ride it out.

"Agustín, to me!" François bellowed through the raging storm. The deck was almost empty, leaving the skeleton of a crew necessary to keep her steady. A sudden wave shook the deck and she stumbled.

"Yes, Captain?" The wind stealing the words, another wave washing over the deck. She kept the grip on the railing ropes.

"If anyone can ride her out, it's Karl. We're trailing as much as we can. If the storm gets heavier ..."

"I will put the engines in reverse at your order, Captain." Wrapping another rope around her arm. "With the modi--"

"Not now, ma chérie." He held up a hand. "I still need your watchful eyes."

A scream resounded through the storm. The hairs on her body rose and she blinked away tears. François lips were moving in prayer, and she joined him, though his was in French and hers in Spanish. "Dios te salve, María, llena eres de gracia ..." As earnestly as Doña Agustína Maria de la Soledad had prayed in the chapel of her father's estate, did Agustín on the deck of a pirate ship. Far from home, far from hearth, far from the life she had been raised to lead.

The morning found them far from their regular route. Agustín stumbled up to help untie Karl from the steering wheel. They were both as soaking wet, but he more exhausted. Miguel, a wiry countryman of Eduardo, replaced him in the calmer winds.

Karl and Agustín supported each other, moving down under deck. Every face she saw gave her comfort. She blinked away tears at the once she didn't see. "Bert?"

Eduardo shook his head, grimacing. "And Boniface. May their souls rest in peace."

Her mind numb from the storm she could but nod, heading to her own cabin. Stripping out of the oilskin coat and boots, she curled up in her cot as she was. It never did get easier to lose friends, be it to storms, battles or disease.

"What's the damage?" She strode up to François. He gave her a tired look, rubbing his goatee.

"Half the fresh water supply. Thanks to good warning from you, not much worse than that." Though he did not mention Bert or Boniface, he didn't need to. "We are still trying to figure out exactly where we are."

"I'll be in the engine room." As she turned, he placed a hand on her shoulder.

"Agustín. We will have a ceremony to honour our lost once we've found our bearings."

She mustered up a hesitant smile, barely nodding as she slunk off.

Minerva found her in the engine room. Her tail was tall, the airs clearly marking her as mistress of the ship. Agustín smiled, petting her soft head. "Hello little one. Exploring your new domains?" The cat flicked her tail, buffing her head against the dirty hand. "Be careful around her. There's plenty of places a little cat can get caught."

Minerva froze, staring into a corner. Agustín squinted, following the cat's gaze. A movement, and then Minerva was off. "Of course. There's also rats."

"Are you talking to yourself?" François amused voice caught her off guard. She changed to English.

"No, to the cat. A proper mouser, by the look of things. Let's hope the ship rats aren't going to be the masters of her."

"It's a cat." He shrugged. "How's the engine looking?"

"A bit wet--some of the water came in here--but nothing worse than that." She tapped the engine a moment. "Do you need Henry?"

His eyebrows raised. "Do I want to know why you're asking that?"

She rolled her eyes, chuckling. "Get your mind out of the gutter, François. I could do with someone smaller to help me." She raised her hand, forestalling his question. "And no, the cat won't be enough. For one, I don't think I can train her to tell me what is wrong where I can't reach."

"Well, I will send him here toute de suite. When we reach port next, if he is not good enough ..."

"We will find someone there." She nodded. "For now he is."

Henry gave her an apprehensive and diffident look as he slunk into the engine room. "You ... had need of me?"

"Yes. Have you ever worked with an engine before?"

"No ... We had only sails, and the Navy wouldn't let me near the engine, even if I wanted to." Fidgeting under her sharp gaze.

"Good. Then I'll just start from the beginning."

Under his dazed attention she went through what they could see of the engines, explaining each piece. Finally he held up his hands; a shield against the torrent of English mixed with Spanish.

"Please, Agustín ... I don't understand half of this. It might as well be Greek. Or, well." He flashed her a brief grin. "Spanish."

"Philistine." She grinned in return. "Spanish is the language of the Queen. May she return to her throne."

He chuckled. "I think my Queen would disagree." His blue-grey eyes flashed with mirth. She chuckled, nodding lightly.

"Very well, I will try to explain it in an easier way." She was unable to stop herself. "So that even an English mind can understand."

She stood up on deck, watching the island approach. François stood at the wheel, proud and strong even as grief muted the humour in his dark eyes.

"Henry!"

"Aye Captain?" The youngster straightened up from his lounging.

"Have you ever sounded a ship into safety by yourself? No? Alright. Agustín, show Henry how to sound using your contraption. I want plenty of warning."

"Aye Captain." She fetched the half-mechanical prototype, walking with the rolling gait of someone used to compensate for the waves. Henry wached her curiously while she showed how to use it.

"I don't get you."

She raised an eyebrow at him. "Oh? What is it you don't get?"

"Just ... you're a woman!"

She didn't bother denying it. "I would be careful with who you said such things to. Now pay attention."

"Yes, but ... Ow!" The back of her hand clipped him over the forehead.

"That was a warning blow. You see this dial here?"

François watched their exchange, a flicker of sardonic amusement, his hands light on the wheel.

The Seadragon danced along the glittering waves. Above them seagulls laughed and screeched; as if the storm of the night had never happened, or maybe that the world had washed its' hands of it. Under Agustín's watchful eyes, Henry called out the depths he read on the contraption.

Once they'd dropped anchors and steadied the ship, François called all sailors onto deck.

"Three groups. Two to explore, one to stay on the ship. Each leader has a horn. Normal signals: two short for danger, three long for water or other resource."

Agustín led one of the two expeditions, her mind wandering as they rowed to the small island. Miguel threw her a glance.

"What's on your mind?"

She blinked out of her reverie. "Something I saw in the diary we found. Trying to figure out if we could make the Seadragon fly."

"Fly?" He blinked, repeating it in English. "Make the ship fly?"

"Well, the theory is sound." She shrugged. "Not with wings. With some kind of big balloon, anchored to ... most likely the railing."

He threw his hands out in an apologetic gesture. "I don't know ciência."

The banter lightened her heart, even as she tensed. There was something ... She forestalled more comments with a raised hand. Her lips parted as she tried to localize the source of unease.

"Ambush! Back to the ship!" Blowing the horn twice. Another ironclad, under sail to stay silent, rounded the island. The brief scent of fuel permeated the air again, as they rowed under curses. The flag of Spain waved proudly from the rigging. Carlists. Was this a stroke of bad luck, or had they been trying to find the Seadragon?

Waves from the larger ironclad pummeled the row boats. They had gotten farthest away from the Seadragon, so to her gratitude the other sailors were climbing up the side. A shot whizzed through the air. Again the Seadragon rocked. The last thing she remembered was flying through the air and into the cold water. One of the oars hit her, and unconscious blackness took her.

item.title: Småty
item.dc:creator: webmaster
item.content:encoded:
These are the summaries for four (or so ...) books revolving around Swedish folklore. Småty is a collection term for the various supernatural critters, from Bohuslän, which is where most of the books take place.

Vendela's story

While dancing at her part-time job (a burlesque strip club in Stockholm), journalism student Vendela meets the rich playboy Andrej, who is immediately smitten with the enticing, chilly blonde. In his pursuit of her, the paparazzi gets a perfect shot of the two dancing, which triggers the instincts of a stalker intent of owning Vendela body and soul. Struggling with connecting the dots between her nightmares, a brutal murder and her increasingly possessive stalker, she is faced with the prospect that it might be Andrej who is behind all of it. Putting her journalistic abilities to the test, she follows him through Stockholm, until they are both faced with the true menace: an immortal mage who kills magical women to gain their powers; the same person who murdered her parents, sending her into the darkest, most damaged recesses of her broken mind. Finally having accepted the truth about magic and her role in things, Vendela takes her new-found knowledge, partial stability and shapeshifting boyfriend to face Blutwald, banishing him and freeing his victims forever.

Sia's & Katja's story

Vendela's best friend (and sister-in-spirit) Sia returns to the west coast of her childhood after a particularly strong argument with her girlfriend Katja (Andrej's ex-firlfriend) in an attempt to find peace and balance. Her absent father shows up at her doorstep, warning her that one of his enemies, the Storsjö Monster, is loose and looking for revenge. When the Monster and its pet mage shows up, he falls into slumber due to his wounds, but not before bequeathing Odin's runes to her. Vendela, Andrej and Katja comes at her urging (though Vendela "forgot" to mention that Katja was coming as well), helping her to figure out her new-found magic, but not before the three magical beings are kidnapped by the Monster. Fleeing the scene, Katja stumbles into an old fertility symbol, gaining the powers of a valkyrie, which gives them the edge to destroy the mage through sejd, before once again binding the Monster at the bottom of the lake.

Cecilia's story

Traumatised as the sole survivor of Blutwald's depredations--freed from a life as his sexslave by Vendela and Andrej--Cecilia departs a random train at Tanum station, unaware of where she is, struggling with thoughts of self-harm and self-punishment. Malbrecht--a charming Scot with an uncanny ability to show up whenever she least expects him--stops her from committing suicide, and her crippled relationship with him takes a horrifying turn as he is forced into the underworld by his liege Áedan mac Gabráin (d. 606). Cecilia seeks Sia's help, knowing that she is a sejdkona, and is guided into the underworld by the Valkyrie Katja, where she finds out that the she needs to go to Hel to recover the shade of Genovefa mac Cadeyrn--the King's niece. Blutwald bars her from entering Hel's castle, and Katja is not allowed to help her. Fleeing from her tormentor she ends up lost between worlds and is barred from returning until she finds strength in herself to face Blutwald. After all, he's dead; she won. Returning with Genovefa, Áedan is forced to release Malbrecht, but bans him from ever entering Mag Mell again. (Ending uncertain: She might be forced to choose between Malbrecht and returning home, or ending up stuck in the Underworld, or something else. Either way, Malbrecht isn't likely to return at that point.)

War

An army is preparing to attack an unaware--and ill-equipped--Sweden, with only a few people ready to stand against it. The first to find out about what is going on is Sia and Katja, living at Greby, as the ghostly army of the Scots sweep through Grebbestad and towards Tanum. Though Greby is safe--if only because they are still ghosts--they know it is only a matter of time before it will manifest, unless they figure out who--or what--is controlling it. Depending on how the prior book ends, Sia either contacts Cecilia and they manage to get Malbrecht back, or the summoning brings both of them back. At any rate, at the battle of Tanum church--once Blodbäck--Malbrecht returns to reclaim the allegiance of his warriors. The necromancer is revealed, but before they can act, he cackles like an old woman. The man has been manipulated by Angerboda, the evil witch, who is using him as a spirit horse. He is the gate between Jotunheim and our plane, and she is now free. Jotuns will soon follow. The protagonists now consist of a dead, Scottish war leader, his 300 ghostly men, a Valkyrie, a wolven shapeshifter, a sejdkona, a skogsrå and a (whatever Cecilia ends up as). That will not last long against the Jotuns, and in desperation they find only once solution: To enter Asgard and plead with the Aesir. Odin refuses to hear them. In fact, he chains them up as prisoners. (This should look up, but this one needs to rest a bit. Andrej is supposed to end up one of Odin's ulvhedin, leading an army of Vikings alongside the army of Scots and army of Valkyries.)

item.content:encoded:
A few days ago, I ended up talking a bit extra with the awesome Olivia Foust, one of many writerly tweeps I talk to on an irregular basis. For whatever reason we eventually ended up on her recent partaking in a WIP Blog Tour. She hadn't nominated anyone, so suggested that if I was interested, she would.

I agreed, so here's my contribution. I'm planning on nominating/linking to four of my other awesome tweeps, though I see no reason to pressure them if they are not interested in actually taking part (or, for that matter, have already done it). They're still awesome.

My workspace

That picture's taken on the train, showing Scrivener with this manuscript open, in particular at Chapter 4 (Unexpected Allies). The mug is a latte, and the yellow block is the cellphone I'm surfing via.

Rules

  • Link the person who nominated you
  • Share a bit about your WIP
  • Share the first sentence of your first 3 chapters
  • Nominate 4 people to do the same

Maw of Eternal Darkness

I have several WIPs, but decided to go with the one that I have the most written on. It's Epic Fantasy (I also call it Young Adult, but I've had people claim it doesn't feel that way, so I will leave that up in the air), set in a world inspired by the Norse mythology, as well as other sources of medieval/pre-medieval cultures. It is meant to be fantastic, and even in places have a sense of whimsy. To a large extent it follows the tropes of classic Swedish fairy tales such as Prince Hat Underground.

Originally it started as a small free-writing sketch that promised eroticism, with a barbarian kidnapping a princess from a tower. In the free-writing, the princess turned out to be chained to the wall, which intrigued me. After a while I wanted to get away from the normal tropes, so decided to make the barbarian female, but in the first version it ended coming off as transphobic (at least in my eyes), so I rewrote it.

In the current version, Lynessa is a princess in a somewhat English-esque kingdom called Keer. She is kidnapped by the Wild Hunt and taken to their keep of ice to be their Jarlswoman, the wife of the Jarl (think King) Vanlandi. Among the Northerners clans, gender is decided on the say-so of the spirits, not any physical characteristics, which confuses Lynessa as her supposed-husband is (per her) a woman.

When the Sun-Child (who is carried across the heavens by the Rider) is swallowed by the wolf hunting them, the young Jarl Vanlandi takes it on himself to recover the sun. The spirits--as interpreted by the Vala (Seer)--demand that Lynessa accompany him. Through their adventures, the damsel-y princess finds a strength within she would never have imagined.

My intentions are to post the first act--chapter by chapter, as I revise it to draft 2--on Wattpad, and once it's finished decide whether I will go Indie publishing, or court an agent/publisher.

Chapter 1: The Princess in the Tower

The snow-tinged wind howled outside Lynessa’s tower, rattling the stained glass windows, demanding to be let in.

Chapter 2: The Wild Hunt

The horse--white as curdled milk--whinnied.

Chapter 3: Nothing is normal

In the morning, Lynessa woke up in an unfamiliar bed.

Teaser

And here's the final bit of the final scene of the second act (1st draft, but the action/scene is the same).

Still in her own thoughts she walked through the courtyard, weaving between the stalls. Slowly she became aware of the voices and pointing. When she glanced up her eyes widened. The Vala, sprinting with her skirts gathered, grabbed her arm.

“We need to get inside!” She gasped into her ear. “Come, child.”

Lynessa followed the seer, stumbling as she stared back and up.

And then, there was darkness.
